questions.question_text:
A SysOps administrator is deploying a fleet of over 100 Amazon EC2 instances in an Amazon VPC. After the instances are set up and serving clients, a new DNS server needs to be added to the instances for DNS resolution.
What is the MOST efficient way to make this change?

choices.B: Use AWS OpsWorks to update the DNS server configuration for each instance.
choices.A: Update the DHCP options set for the Amazon VPC.
choices.D: Write a script to update the DNS server configuration for each instance.
choices.C: Use AWS Systems Manager to update the DMS server configuration for each instance.

discussion.content: DHCP Options Set ; easy, and more convenient
option A is correct

I think A is the best answer, in addition its auto-applied to the instances without rebooting
https://wiki.outscale.net/display/EN/Modifying+the+DHCP+Options+Set+Associated+with+a+VPC
I was gonna pick "C" , but the question asks for the most efficient way hence "A" should be the correct answer.
Answer is C because we need to add the new DNS server to the 100 instances, the most efficient way to get this done is use System Manager to automate the configuration

comments.content: So I'm changing my answer to A based on this information: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vpc/latest/userguide/VPC_DHCP_Options.html#AmazonDNS

discussion.content:
Answer: C
System Manager

comments.content: I agree with you. But say if you update it on the VPC level, it will reflect the same settings to every other resource on the VPC. Out of options given A is the best answer. But checking

discussion.content: Answer is A

questions.question_text:
A company wants to track Amazon EC2 usage charges that are based on the value of a tag that is named Business-Unit. Company leaders instruct developers to update all EC2 resources with the tag. The developers notify the leaders that they have completed this task.
Later that week, a finance team member checks Cost Explorer. The finance team member sees EC2 costs in the different accounts but cannot find the Business-
Unit tag to filter by or group by.
What is the MOST likely reason that the Business-Unit tag is absent?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
For tags to be used as cost allocation tags, they need to be activated in the AWS Billing and Cost Management console. Even if the developers have added the Business-Unit tag to the EC2 resources, if it is not activated as a cost allocation tag, it will not appear in Cost Explorer for filtering or grouping the EC2 costs based on that tag.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/awsaccountbilling/latest/aboutv2/activating-tags.html 
As per this link, you need to active the tag in order to consider it as cost allocation tags
Answer : A
Correct

A.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/awsaccountbilling/latest/aboutv2/activating-tags.html
A is correct

choices.B: The Business-Unit tag is not valid because tag key names do not support dashes (-).
choices.C: The instances have been rebooted, and the developers neglected to re-add the Business-Unit tag after the reboot.
choices.A: The Business-Unit tag is not activated as a cost allocation tag in the AWS Billing and Cost Management console.
choices.D: The IAM user does not have permission to view the tags in Cost Explorer.

questions.question_text: A sys admin is maintaining an application on AWS. The application is installed on EC2 and user has configured ELB and Auto Scaling. Considering future load increase, the user is planning to launch new servers proactively so that they get registered with ELB. How can the user add these instances with Auto Scaling?
questions.answer_description:
A user can increase the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group and Auto Scaling will launch a new instance as per the new capacity. The newly launched instances will be registered with ELB if Auto Scaling group is configured with ELB. If the user decreases the minimum size the instances will be removed from Auto
Scaling. Increasing the maximum size will not add instances but only set the maximum instance cap.

discussion.content: Tricky question. "future" is a trap, "proactive" is a clue. So answer should be A.
Correct Answer: A

A is the answer

to launch new machines, you need to increase the desired capacity. Max capacity does not launch any instance, it just limits how many instances can be running in that ASG

comments.content:
I see your point
Auto Scaling Group has 3 capacity setting (Min, Desire, Max). This question does not specify the Max and desire value. Desire value is always lower than max value. You may increase the desire value to achieve the goal as long as it does not exceed the Max value

discussion.content:
you can not increase desire capacity unless the max capacity is increased 
e.g if the max capacity is 4 and you have increased the desired capacity to 5, it will not work as the max capacity is 4

A
As and when new instanced need to be added, just increment the desired capacity and AS will spin new instances that matches the desired capacity.
Increasing the maximum limit will only set the limit :)
proactively suggests the current levels of provisioning i.e. desired capacity - rather than min or max suggesting future levels of provisioning.

comments.content: Your comments are of no value

discussion.content: A. Increase the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group

choices.A: Increase the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group
choices.C: Launch an instance manually and register it with ELB on the fly
choices.D: Decrease the minimum limit of the Auto Scaling group
choices.B: Increase the maximum limit of the Auto Scaling group

questions.question_text:
A SysOps administrator must run a script on production servers to fix an issue. The company has a policy to block all remote interactive access to production servers.
Based on this situation, how should the administrator run the script?

choices.C: Configure the script to run as a cron job or scheduled task on the EC2 instances.
choices.B: Put the script into the user data of the instances.
choices.D: Use AWS Systems Manager to run the script.
choices.A: Share and use the Amazon EC2 key pairs to gain access to the servers and run the script.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the answer

D..
Systems Manager is a Management Tool that enables you gain operational insights and take action on AWS resources safely and at scale. Using the run command, one of the automation features of Systems Manager, you can simplify management tasks by eliminating the need to use bastion hosts, SSH, or remote PowerShell.
Answer : D

D
since no interactive access
D is the right answer

According to this: https://aws.amazon.com/getting-started/hands-on/remotely-run-commands-ec2-instance-systems-manager/

Ans: D) Use AWS Systems Manager to run the script.
